newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU Court upholds Eurotunnel usage contract.
newsitem.headline: EU Court upholds Eurotunnel usage contract.

text.p: The European Court rejected on Tuesday a European Commission decision to force French and British rail companies to allow competition through the channel tunnel because it was based on factual error.

British Rail (BR) and Societe Nationale des Chemins de Fer Francais (SNCF) successfully showed the court that third parties have always had access to the tunnel, and the Commission's evaluation of the tunnel usage was based in error.

In fact, Eurotunnel SA, the joint venture between BR and SNCF secures only 50 percent of the capacity for international trains, not 100 percent as the Commission claimed, according to the European Court of First Instance judgment.
British Rail said in 1994 in a letter to the Commission that there was a "profound misunderstanding" on the part of the Commission over the usage contract governing access to the tunnel.

Alex Nourry, a competition lawyer based in Brussels with Clifford Chance said the decision means the usage contract for the tunnel was not contrary to competition rules and also removes conditions the Commission set on the railway operators under its 1994 decision.

The Commission required BR and SNCF to make available to competitors 25 percent of the hourly capacity of the tunnel in each direction since 1994 when the decision was taken. Since then, no third parties have come forward to exercise this right, Nourry said.
Nourry also said the decision may have major implications for other Trans European Network projects.
"If the EU wants to promote private financing for transportation projects, it must let individuals exploit long term contracts," Nourry said.
